review.title: This before That: Causal Precedence in the Biomedical Domain
review.abstract: Causal precedence between biochemical interactions is crucial in the biomedical domain, because it transforms collections of individual interactions, e.g., bindings and phosphorylations, into the causal mechanisms needed to inform meaningful search and inference. Here, we analyze causal precedence in the biomedical domain as distinct from open-domain, temporal precedence. First, we describe a novel, hand-annotated text corpus of causal precedence in the biomedical domain. Second, we use this corpus to investigate a battery of models of precedence, covering rule-based, feature-based, and latent representation models. The highest-performing individual model achieved a micro F1 of 43 points, approaching the best performers on the simpler temporal-only precedence tasks. Feature-based and latent representation models each outperform the rule-based models, but their performance is complementary to one another. We apply a sieve-based architecture to capitalize on this lack of overlap, achieving a micro F1 score of 46 points.
histories: To appear in the proceedings of the 2016 Workshop on Biomedical Natural Language Processing (BioNLP 2016)
review.COMMENTS: To appear in the proceedings of the 2016 Workshop on Biomedical Natural Language Processing (BioNLP 2016)

metadata.title: This before That: Causal Precedence in the Biomedical Domain

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, it has been shown that people are able to survive themselves if they do not put themselves in a position to survive.

sections.heading: 2 A Corpus for Causal Precedence in the Biomedical Domain
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead in order to achieve the objectives I have mentioned.

sections.heading: 3 Models of Causal Precedence
sections.text: We have developed both deterministic, interpretable models and automatic machine learning models to demonstrate causal precedent in our dataset. Importantly, the models discussed in this paper focus exclusively on causal precedent, which is the most complex relationship described in the previously presented dataset. Therefore, for all the experiments discussed here, we reduce these notes to three terms: "E1 precedes E2," "E2 precedes E1," and Nil, which covers all other terms in the7Similar to pair programming.corpus.

sections.heading: 3.1 Deterministic Models
sections.text: Deterministic models are defined by a small number of handwritten rules, which include the aspect of Odin-Esca-rcega et al., 2015b). The number of rules for each model is shown in the table, and the aspect of general linguistic knowledge is introduced later (Table 3), which is used by our machine learning models. In order to avoid a large variety of deterministic models, all were created without reference to the annotation corpus, using general linguistic knowledge and domain knowledge.

sections.heading: 3.2 Feature-based Models
sections.text: Most cases of causal precedent cannot be grasped by deterministic rules because they lack explicit words, phrases, or syntactic structures that clearly characterize this relationship. By combining the surface, syntactic, and taxonomic characteristics outlined in Table 3, we trained a number of statistical classifiers to detect causal precedent relationships between pairs of events in our corpus. For training and testing purposes, we treated as a negative example any instance that was not labeled "E1 before E2" or "E2 before E1." We examined the following statistical models: a linear core SVM (Chang and Lin, 2011), logistic regression (Fan et al., 2008), and random forest9 (Surdeanu et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.3 Latent Representation Models
sections.text: In fact, we find ourselves able to stir and stir up the aforementioned brainlcsrcüehcS in order to stir them up.

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: We summarize the performance of all these models on the dataset previously introduced in Table 4. We report on results with microprecision, recall and F1 scores for each model. With less than 200 cases of causal precedent occurring in 1000 annotations, training and testing was performed for both the label-based classifiers and for latent feature models with stratified 10-fold cross-validation. For the latent feature models, training was parameterized to a maximum of 100. Furthermore, the binding of nucleotide-free Ras to PI3KC2β inhibits its lipid kinase activity. PI3KC2β and Ras complexes can then be transferred to distal sites, such as early endosomes (EE), where ITSN1 then binds to PI3KC2β, resulting in the release of nucleotide-free Ras and the activation of lipid kinase activity.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: Overall, the results are promising, especially in light of the deliberate decision to omit (causal) regulatory responses in this task, since they are already covered by the reach reading system. However, the deterministic models created so far remember extremely little, making it difficult to determine their accuracy. An analysis of the Reichenbach model reveals a source of this limited reach. In short, although authors could describe causal mechanisms using temporal indicators such as tension and aspect, a temporal description in this area is rare enough not to be represented in our randomly sampled database. Table 5 illustrates the lack of overlap with informative time aspect combinations; a single tense is used per pass, and no perfect aspect is used. Likewise, the time expressions required by the deterministic precedent rules within and between sentences are rare enough to render them ineffective in this sample.

sections.heading: 5.1 Model overlap
sections.text: As Chambers et al. (2014), Mirza (2016) and many other algorithms have shown, models can be applied sequentially in "sevens" to achieve higher quality results. Ideally, each model in a sieve-based system captures different portions of the data through a mixture of approaches, making this method different from more naive ensembles in which the contributions of a single component would be washed out. Figure 8 describes this observation by showing the coverage difference between the models described here.439411622133 14 0166LSTM LSTM + PFLSTM FLSTM + P (a) Intersect of true positive predictions by LSTM models. Although the models in Table 4 seem to be similar, the representations learned in their coverage are largely different and complementary.

sections.heading: 5.2 Error analysis
sections.text: We conducted an analysis of the false positions common to all feature-based classifiers, in addition to the false negatives common to all models. At this point, we limit our discussion to the most prominent feature shared by the majority of false positives. Discourse information More than half of the false positions have contrastive discourse features that indicate that a discourse model could improve discrimination against classifiers. Example 8 shows such a contrasting structure in which a clause (and an event) is introduced that is contrastive and therefore both temporally and causally distinguishable from the following clause (and the event).

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Although they focused on the temporal order, Chambers et al. (2014) adopted a seven-based approach, with high-precision deterministic sieves preceding and limiting more precise, precise machine-learning sieves. As with our system, deterministic sieves were linguistically motivated and had the added advantage of using expressions over time (during, on Friday, etc.), as well as events that are typically absent from the biomedical domain. Mirza (2016) implemented a hybrid seven-based approach to detecting causal relationships between events, including a set of causal verbal rules and corresponding syntactic dependencies, as well as a label-based classic. However, both work focus on open-domain texts. To our knowledge, we are the first to investigate causal precedent cases in the biomedical domain.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: These are the first experiments on the automatic annotation of causal precedents in the biomedical field. Although the lack of temporal expressions and other regular linguistic cues makes the task particularly difficult in this area, the initial results are promising and show that a seven-based system of models tested here improves performance over the most powerful single component. Both the annotation corpus and the models described here represent major steps towards linking automatic reading with a larger, more informative biological mechanism.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work was funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) under the ARO contract W911NF-141-0395.

referenceMentions.context: There is a tremendous ongoing effort (Nédellec et al., 2013; Kim et al., 2012; Kim et al., 2009) to extract individual chemical interactions from these texts, but these interactions are only isolated fragments of larger causal mechanisms such as protein signaling pathways.

There is a tremendous ongoing effort (Nédellec et al., 2013; Kim et al., 2012; Kim et al., 2009) to extract individual chemical interactions from these texts, but these interactions are only isolated fragments of larger causal mechanisms such as protein signaling pathways.

The absence of such a database is not for lack of trying; Pathway Commons (Cerami et al., 2011) aims to address the need, but its authors estimate it currently covers 1% of the literature due to the high cost of annotation1.

The Big Mechanism program (Cohen, 2015) aims to construct exactly such large-scale mechanistic information by reading and assembling protein signaling pathways that are relevant for cancer, and exploit them to generate novel explanatory and treatment hypotheses.

Although prior work (Chambers et al., 2014; Mirza, 2016) has addressed the challenging area of temporal precedence in the open domain, the biomedical domain presents very different data and, consequently, requires novel techniques.

Though event temporality is crucial to understanding electronic health records for individual patients (Bethard et al., 2015; Bethard et al., 2016), its contribution to the understanding of biomolecular reactions is less clear as these events and processes may repeat in extremely short cycles, continue without end, or overlap in time.

metadata.abstractText: Causal precedence between biochemical interactions is crucial in the biomedical domain, because it transforms collections of individual interactions, e.g., bindings and phosphorylations, into the causal mechanisms needed to inform meaningful search and inference. Here, we analyze causal precedence in the biomedical domain as distinct from open-domain, temporal precedence. First, we describe a novel, hand-annotated text corpus of causal precedence in the biomedical domain. Second, we use this corpus to investigate a battery of models of precedence, covering rule-based, feature-based, and latent representation models. The highestperforming individual model achieved a micro F1 of 43 points, approaching the best performers on the simpler temporalonly precedence tasks. Feature-based and latent representation models each outperform the rule-based models, but their performance is complementary to one another. We apply a sieve-based architecture to capitalize on this lack of overlap, achieving a micro F1 score of 46 points.
